p: The last vernacular name with an African etymology, tapete de Oxalá (rug of Oxalá in English, Episcia cupreata), is also used in other parts of Brazil for other plant species [ 25]. Oxalá is a Candomblé deity and has a West African etymology, but it is unknown when and how this name was introduced into the Brazilian Portuguese vocabulary [ 24], and therefore how and by whom Episcia cupreata was first associated with this deity.
